content:
ASIA-PAC

China's SAFE abolished 17 regulations on FX management to promote trade and investment facilitation. (Xinhua)


UK

UK Cabinet was told by the Chief Whip the Brexit backstop does not have enough votes and will not pass Parliament. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Hammond is said to warn MPs Britain will face a GBP 36bln bill if it fails to reach a trade agreement with EU. (Telegraph)

European Commission is said to have offered UK to remain in the Customs Union beyond December 2020. (FAZ)

EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier said will work seriously for a Brexit deal in the coming weeks and wants to avoid a hard border in-between Northern Ireland and Ireland. In addition, Barnier said we have worked a lot to find an overall deal for a orderly withdrawal of the UK, while Barnier is also reported to see December as the 'ultimate deadline' for a Brexit deal. (Newswires)

EU Council President Tusk said there are no grounds for optimism on Brexit, while he added he will ask PM May if she has concrete proposals to break impasse and only such proposals could move talks. However, Tusk also commented that there is a will and determination on both sides. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (8 Oct) -2.13mln vs. Exp. +2.2mln (Prev. +9.75mln). (Newswires)

Iran has seen a 'significant decrease' in oil exports since the US pulled out the nuclear deal and began imposing sanctions, according to a senior administration official. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he spoke with the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia who totally denied any knowledge of what took place in the Turkish consulate regarding journalist Jamal Khashoggi. (Newswires)

Talks between the Saudis and Kuwait to restart two shared oil fields have reportedly broken down. (Platts)


US

Fed Chair Powell said he is concerned about the spillover effects from a hard Brexit, while there were also comments from US Treasury's Malpass that a hard Brexit without transition would be a risk. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (Voter) said inflation is effectively at 2% target and that labor market has surpassed full employment, while she also commented that growth is robust. (Newswires)

US President Trump said his biggest threat is the Fed because it is hiking rates too fast and said he is not so happy with people he appointed to the Fed other than Fed Chairman Powell. (Fox/Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer is to open trade talks with the EU, UK and Japan. (Newswires)

Data Recap
US Industrial Production MM Sep 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
US Manufacturing Production MM Sep 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.3%)
US Capacity Utilization SA Sep 78.1% vs. Exp. 78.2% (Prev. 78.1%)
US JOLTS Job Openings Aug 7.136M vs. Exp. 6.945M (Prev. 6.939M, Rev. 7.077M)

Notable Earnings
CSX Corp (CSX) Q3 EPS USD 1.05 vs. Exp. USD 0.94, revenue USD 3.13bln vs. Exp. USD 3.05bln.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc (GS) Q3 EPS USD 6.28 vs. Exp. USD 5.38, revenue USD 8.65bln vs. Exp. USD 8.37bln
IBM (IBM) Q3 operating EPS USD 3.42 vs. Exp. USD 3.4, revenue USD 18.8bln vs. Exp. USD 19.11bln. Reaffirms 2018 guidance
Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) Q3 non-Gaap EPS ex-items USD 2.05 vs. Exp. USD 2.03, raises sales and EPS guidance.
Morgan Stanley (MS) Q3 Diluted EPS USD 1.17 vs. Exp. USD 1.01, revenue USD 9.9bln vs. Exp. USD 9.56bln.
Netflix Inc (NFLX) Q3 EPS USD 0.89 vs. Exp. USD 0.68, International subscriber additions 5.87mln vs. Exp. 4.35mln.
 

MARKET RECAP

Adobe (ADBE) was a heavyweight gainer on the day after investors were reassured by its backing of previous earnings forecasts and 2019 targets, contributing to the tech sectors outperformance. Banks Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) moved higher after topping earnings estimates. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) pulled up the healthcare sector on the back of beating earnings estimates and raising forecasts for the year. Tesla (TSLA) was another top mover following Elon Musk tweeting the implementation of a new chip in its cars which will improve autopilot features. W.W. Grainger (GWW) and BlackRock (BLK) were bottom movers today after both their earnings beat estimates but revenues missed. Other stocks down, on what otherwise was a largely positive day, were AutoZone (AZO), Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) and Comerica (CMA). SPX +2.2% at 2750.78, NDX +2.9% at 7276, DJI +2.2% at 25798.

Treasuries were mixed, with only modest movement in yields within tight ranges. There was a bias towards curve flattening, though major spreads were only modestly narrower, with some analysts suggesting flatteners were being put on in pre-FOMC minutes trade (Weds, see below for preview). The lack meaningful moves helped contribute to a firmer risk tone after the release of a solid JOLTs survey for August, falling equity volatility, as well as generally upbeat earnings reports. JPMorgan's latest client Treasury survey found active clients cutting longs to below the four-week average, while shorts were also pared back, and consequently, neutrals rose, taking net positioning to the top of its monthly range. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 2 ticks higher at 118-07.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 16 October 2018: Firmer risk sentiment spurs equity rebound after stellar JOLTs
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries mixed, crude up, dollar flat; risk sentiment firms after solid data, lower vol, upbeat earnings.
  • * REAR-VIEW: JOLTs beat big, VIX moderates, EU sceptical on Italy’s budget; Tusk pessimistic on Brexit; Industrial Production, NAHB, evidence found that Khashoggi was killed in Turkey, Trump renews Fed criticism.
  • * AHEAD: FOMC mins; UK, EZ inflation; Fed's Brainard; BMO earnings USD, MTB, NTRS, ABT; AMC earnings KMI, CCI

* BREXIT: EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier stated ‘we will work seriously for a Brexit deal in the coming weeks’, though EU Council President Tusk was more explicit, stating there were no grounds for optimism in Brexit talks; at the summit on Wednesday, Tusk will ask UK PM May if she has concrete proposals to break the impasse, adding that only such proposals could move talks. With regards to a timescale, an official said that Brexit talks are on track for November, though  Irish PM Varadkar repeated that the deadline for a Brexit deal could slip from October (on Monday he suggested December); he nonetheless strongly believes a no-deal Brexit is unlikely. Similarly, EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier sees December as the 'ultimate deadline' for a deal. On the EU side, a Senior official said a December Brexit agreement could work for the EU but could mean a tight schedule for the UK parliament, adding it is not going to be easy to find a deal. Elsewhere, The Telegraph reported UK Cabinet Ministers should pressure UK PM May to abandon her Chequers plan or Tory Eurosceptic MPs will threaten a no confidence vote within days. In late trade, sources said the UK government Cabinet was told by the Chief Whip that the Brexit backstop will not pass Parliament, since it does not have enough votes. In later reports, the European Commission said to have offered UK to remain in the Customs Union beyond December 2020.

* ITALY: The Italian Government confirmed the 2.4% deficit/GDP target for 2019 and 1.2% economic growth forecast for 2018 with a Parliament watchdog not validating the economic forecasts. In an interview with CNBC, Italian Lega Economic adviser Borghi stated that Italy are open to compromise on the budget whilst Italian PM Conte said that they are proud of the budget and they hope for a positive dialogue with Brussels. In response, EU Commission President Juncker noted the Italian public finance is a cause of great concern, hinting Brussels may reject the country’s fiscal plan. He stressed there is no prejudice in Brussels against Italy though he stated the Eurozone would rebel if the EU approves the budget. Moreover, European Commission VP Dombrovskis stated the EU has already assessed the 2.4% Italy deficit target. In terms of components, the budget was touted not to include a tax incentives to encourage domestic retail investors to buy government bonds but the measure could be added as an amendment in Parliament.

* TRADE: EU's Trade Commissioner Malmstrom said if the US imposes 25% tariffs, the EU must react, adding that they are making efforts not to lose time in trade talks but do not want a deadline. Elsewhere, USTR is to open trade talks with the EU, UK and Japan.

* GEOPOLITICS: Turkish officials reported that evidence has been found within the Saudi consulate that Khashoggi was killed there; this came after US Senate Majority McConnell announced that if reports about the missing journalist are found to be true, the Senate is likely to act. A US Administration official then indicated the US has an important relationship with Saudi Arabia, though this does not mean it is ignoring other issues with the Kingdom. Elsewhere, US National Security Advisor Bolton is to meet Russia's Security Council Secretary and Russian Foreign Ministry in Moscow next week. Finally, it was reported the Trump administration has a new plan to drive Iran out of Syria by squeezing it financially alongside other efforts.

* FED: US President Trump renewed criticism of the Fed ahead of the FOMC Minutes on Wednesday saying 'my biggest threat is the Fed' and adding the Fed is independent and he does not speak to them, in a Fox Business interview.

* INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION for September came in strong positing at 0.3%. above the 0.2% consensus. Analysts at Wells Fargo note that higher oil prices continue to support mining activity which rose by 0.5% last month; manufacturing also rose 0.2% on the back of gains in motor vehicles. Further to this, Hurricane Florence seems to have had limited impact on the data. Wells Fargo however highlights that total industrial production is has slowed down over the quarter and they expect further ‘moderation in the coming months amid

slower global growth, a strong dollar, ongoing trade tensions and rising rates’.

* JOLTS: The number of openings rose to 7.136mln in August, above the expected 6.945mln, hitting another new high. The prior was also revised up to 7.077mln. Analysts at Pantheon noted that the strong reading is consistent with other private surveys which are showing that labour demand is rising much faster than supply. They further noted that the quits rate was unchanged at 2.4% and they do not expect any further increase this year. The data, which doesn’t often move markets, saw a positive, bullish reaction, helping stocks to rebound after their recent slide, which also contributed to a firmer risk tone.

* NAHB Index rose to 68 in October against a previous and 67; analysts at Pantheon highlight the reading was boosted by the buyer traffic index which rose to a nine-month high. Nonetheless they argue ‘some uptick in sales in the next couple of months is a reasonable bet, but a sustained upward trend is too much to hope for;’ as they believe housing market has peaked for this cycle.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Adobe (ADBE) was a heavyweight gainer on the day after investors were reassured by its backing of previous earnings forecasts and 2019 targets, contributing to the tech sectors outperformance. Banks Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) moved higher after topping earnings estimates. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) pulled up the healthcare sector on the back of beating earnings estimates and raising forecasts for the year. Tesla (TSLA) was another top mover following Elon Musk tweeting the implementation of a new chip in its cars which will improve autopilot features. W.W. Grainger (GWW) and BlackRock (BLK) were bottom movers today after both their earnings beat estimates but revenues missed. Other stocks down, on what otherwise was a largely positive day, were AutoZone (AZO), Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) and Comerica (CMA).

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD 0.14 HIGHER AT USD 71.92/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.63 HIGHER AT USD 81.41/BBL. In early US trade, crude was trading cautious, with traders expecting weekly inventory data to show a build in headline crude stocks of 2.2mln, Cushing stocks are expected to build (by 282k vs 9/Oct, and 1.76mln vs 5/Oct); products are seen drawing, with distillates stocks expected to fall by 1.3mln, while gasoline stocks are seen slipping by 1.1mln. The crude complex picked up in later trade, as it tracked improving risk sentiment, following a solid JOLTs report out of the US, falling VIX, and investors encouraged by decent corporate earnings. In other news, traders continue to monitor news flow regarding the 'missing' journalist in Turkey, and PVM argued that Saudis have denied any involvement and after US President floated the idea of a 'rouge killer', at present it does not seem likely that Saudi oil supply will be negatively affected by the incident at this stage. Elsewhere, traders continue to cite EIA data from earlier in the week which showed US shale production is expected to rise by 100k in November to 7.71mln BPD.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 2 TICKS HIGHER AT 118-07. Treasuries were mixed, with only modest movement in yields within tight ranges. There was a bias towards curve flattening, though major spreads were only modestly narrower, with some analysts suggesting flatteners were being put on in pre-FOMC minutes trade (Weds, see below for preview). The lack meaningful moves helped contribute to a firmer risk tone after the release of a solid JOLTs survey for August, falling equity volatility, as well as generally upbeat earnings reports. JPMorgan's latest client Treasury survey found active clients cutting longs to below the four-week average, while shorts were also pared back, and consequently, neutrals rose, taking net positioning to the top of its monthly range.

 * DXY: Drifted below the 95.00 handle to fresh October lows at 94.789, with the index and Dollar in general unable to glean any real support from a marginal beat in US industrial production, an upbeat JOLTS report, and an uptick in the NAHB index. The DXY moved back towards the 95.00 figure where it has been consolidating in late trade.

* GBP: The Pound remains relatively resilient despite ongoing Brexit uncertainty and a raft of official opinion that the risk of a no deal is now greater than it has been. However, PM May called for unity from her cabinet and reported no signs of anybody threatening to resign, while UK data in the form of average earnings also underpinned Sterling, with Cable probing higher above 1.3200 and nearer to 1.3250 and Eur/Gbp back below 0.8800 towards 0.8750 at one stage.

* EUR: The single currency failed to sustain another 1.1600+ foray vs the Greenback, with technical resistance at a key DMA capping the pair and some fundamental weights impacting via a disappointing ZEW survey and persistent EU angst over elements of Italy’s budget (ie Juncker reiterating grave concerns about the country’s fiscal situation).

* NZD: The Kiwi is retesting overnight peaks just shy of 0.6600 vs the Usd, as the Greenback extends losses vs most counterparts bar the traditional safe-havens. To recap, the Nzd derived independent impetus from Q3 CPI data showing headline inflation data above consensus and closer to the RBNZ’s 2% target at 1.9% y/y.

* CAD: Another major beneficiary of weakness in its US peer and continuing its rebound from recent lows under 1.3000 towards 1.2925.

* AUD: Still lagging behind its antipodean counterpart with the cross hovering around 1.0850, but regaining some lost ground vs the Usd as 0.7100 held firm.

* CHF, JPY: Bucking the overall trend for the bulk if not entire EU session, as the Franc retreated to 0.9900 vs the Usd and extended losses through 1.1450 against the Eur, reversing course from the end of last week and yesterday, while the Jpy failed to seriously challenge a sub-112.00 fib and nibbled at bids said to be relatively generously stacked up to 112.50.

* SEK: More hawkish Riksbank prospects and heightened expectations of a lift-off in the repo at December’s policy meeting post-last week’s strong Swedish inflation data gave the Krona another boost, with Eur/Sek down through key chart support and almost breaching 10.3000.

* COMING-UP - FOMC September 2018 Meeting Minutes due on 17th October 2018 at 1400 EST/1900 BST. FOMC hiked rates by 25bps at its September meeting, as was expected, and removed the reference in its statement that policy is 'accommodative'. Forecasts were little changed, though the central bank's new dot sees rates at between 3.25-3.50% in 2021, matching the level of its 2020 projection, hinting that the FOMC has put a soft end-date to its hiking cycle. Additionally, it appears that the FOMC does not intend to raise rates above its estimate of neutral (the broadest estimate of the Fed's neutral rate range, determined from FOMC speakers over the past few months, is between 2.50-3.50%). In his press conference, Powell endorsed a gradual approach, and noted that some participants saw a moderate overshoot of neutral rate. Click here to access the full RANsquawk Preview.

subject: Italy's budget does not include a tax incentives to encourage domestic retail investors to buy government bonds but the measure could be added as an amendment in Parliament; according to a government source
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italy’s FTSE MIB outperforms amid signals the Italian government is working together after the budget was approved by Parliament
  • GBP derived enough momentum from higher than forecast UK average earnings to breach 1.3200 to the upside
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Hungarian interest rate decision, US industrial production and weekly API crude inventories.

Asian equity markets partially shrugged-off the tech-led losses on Wall St and traded mostly higher as focus shifted on earnings updates. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was led by mining names after the recent strength in gold prices and with Rio Tinto shares supported following its Q3 production update in which iron ore shipments declined Y/Y but the Co. affirmed FY18 shipments at the upper end of its guidance range. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) and Japanese exporters coat-tailed on favourable currency moves, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.9 %) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) initially conformed to the upbeat tone as participants brushed aside continued PBoC liquidity inaction and took encouragement from the numerous corporate positive profit alerts, although Chinese bourses then failed to sustain the gains and gradually slipped into negative territory. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they tracked weakness in T-notes, with prices also subdued by the improved risk tone in Japan and reduced demand at the 5yr JGB auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations again for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9119 (Prev. 6.9154)

Chinese CPI (Sep) Y/Y 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.3%)
Chinese PPI (Sep) Y/Y 3.6% vs. Exp. 3.5% (Prev. 4.1%)

EU/UK/US

UK Leader of the Commons, Andrea Leadsom hosted a meeting in her office last night with 8 ministers who share concerns over PM May’s Brexit plans. The Telegraph suggests that the scale and the seniority of the meeting is likely to be of concern for Downing Street. (Telegraph)

Austrian EU minister says that Brexit negotiation dynamics are going in the right direction, but not enough for a compromise yet. (Newswires)

French Government is confident a Brexit deal can be reached but not on Wednesday night, adding that time is running out. (Newswires)

German EU minister Roth says the EU has gone a long way towards the UK's position on Brexit; saying that we need a watertight Irish backstop. (Newswires). German government official says they see Germany as well equipped for all Brexit scenarios; also adds that a Brexit agreement is ruled out without a solution for the Irish border. (Newswires)

UK Cabinet Ministers should pressure UK PM May to abandon her Chequers plan or Tory Eurosceptic MPs will threaten a no confidence vote within days, according to the Telegraph. (Newswires)

According to a Senior EU official having a Brexit summit in November is not a given; this weeks’ summit will decide whether there is enough progress to call a summit. With the EU insisting that the economic section of PM May’s Chequers plan will not work. (Newswires)

EU's Trade Commissioner Malmstrom says if US imposes 25% tariffs, the EU must react, adding that they are making efforts not to lose time in trade talks but do not want a deadline. (Newswires)

Italian Government confirmed 2.4% deficit/GDP target for 2019 and 1.2% economic growth forecast for 2018. Parliament watchdog did not validate economic forecasts. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy DI Maio says the Italian bond yield spread is a temporary situation; it is not supposed to remain like this. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte says that they are proud of the budget and they hope for a positive dialogue with Brussels. (Newswires)

Italian Lega Economic adviser Borghi states that Italy are open to compromise. (Newswires)

EU Commission Head Juncker states that the Eurozone would rebel if the EU approves the Italian budget. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Most major European indices (ex-FTSE 100) are in the green, with Italy’s FTSE MIB (+1.1%) outperforming its peers amid signals the Italian government is working together after the budget was approved by Parliament. Meanwhile, the UK benchmark is pressured by a firmer currency along with heavy-weight mining names following price action in the complex. Sectors are mixed, with utilities names outperforming while energy names lag given the recent slump in oil prices.

In terms of individual stocks, Volvo shares fell over 5% after the detection of premature degradation of emission control components. On the flip side, Drax Group are up by over 4.5% after the company acquired a UK power generation portfolio with a proposed deal for GBP 702mln, while Altice share rose 5% following commentary that Co. has Mirova, Macquaries and KKR as frontrunners for a fibre JV.

FX

NZD/GBP

The Kiwi has been boosted by stronger than expected NZ CPI data overnight, and almost rallied to 0.6600 vs the Usd, while the Pound derived enough momentum from higher than forecast UK average earnings to breach 1.3200, albeit briefly amidst ongoing Brexit fall-out from the failure to clinch an agreement in time for this week’s EU summit that in turn was a prerequisite for another one in November to finalise a withdrawal deal.

CAD/EUR/AUD

All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, as the DXY continues to pivot 95.000, with the Loonie rebounding from recent 1.3000+ lows after a somewhat mixed BoC business survey on Monday (are rather redundant given that it was conducted pre-USMCA), while the single currency stalled around 1.1600 again and hampered by downbeat ZEW investor sentiment readings. Eur/Usd is just holding above 1.1565 lows, but could be drawn towards hefty option expiries at the 1.1550 strike (1.3 bn ahead of the NY cut). Elsewhere, the Aud did not get any independent support from RBA minutes largely sticking to a neutral stance, but has been caught in the cross-fire from relative Nzd outperformance as that pairing retreats through 1.0900 and 1.0850, plus ‘strong’ technical support between 1.0860-35 along the way.

JPY/CHF   

A reversal in fortunes for the safe-havens as Asia-Pac stocks put in a relatively resilient performance after recent heavy declines and with Usd/Jpy rebounding off a Fib (111.60) to trade back over 112.00, albeit now running in to decent supply said to be layered all the way up to 112.50. Note also, some big expiry interest containing the pair, with 3.1 bn from 111.60-75 and 1.3 bn at 112.50-65. The Franc has retreated from just shy of 0.9850 to meander within a 0.9900-0.9865 range.

FIXED INCOME

A relatively downbeat ZEW survey nudged Bunds just over parity to a new 158.61 Eurex peak (+2 ticks vs -1/4 point at worst), and appears to be protecting the core Eurozone debt future from further outperformance at the margins, as Italian BTPs continue to squeeze higher. Indeed, following pretty positive comments from Eurogroup head Centeno who stated that Italy does not pose a risk, the 10 year bond has rallied over 121.00, albeit belatedly, while Portuguese paper extends its post-S&P outlook upgrade ascent. However, Gilts and US Treasuries remain close to their lows post-UK data and pre-IP respectively.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are both lower by over 0.5% with the prices approaching USD 71.00/bbl and USD 81.00/bbl to the downside respectively in anticipation of an increase in U.S inventories, where the EIA noted shale oil output is expected to rise to a record 7.7mln BPD in November. Traders will be keeping an eye on the weekly API crude inventory data released later today and any developments in Saudi in regards to the missing journalist.

Gold is marginally higher in a continuation of market risk aversion as investors seek the yellow metal; with prices pivoting near two-and-a-half month highs. Elsewhere, copper slid 1.5% with the red metal facing its biggest one-day loss in over a week as escalating US-Sino trade tensions weighed on sentiment and demand outlook. Meanwhile, steel demand forecasts from WorldSteel have doubled for both 2018 and 2019, although trade tensions mean that industry risks remain. Finally, Chinese rebar futures pulled back from near-four-week highs, while analysts noted that steel prices in China will remain supported by the country’s resolve to reduce excess and outdated capacity.

Sectors are mixed, with utilities names outperforming while energy names lag given the recent slump in oil prices.

In terms of individual stocks, Volvo shares fell over 5% after the detection of premature degradation of emission control components. On the flip side, Drax Group are up by over 4.5% after the company acquired a UK power generation portfolio with a proposed deal for GBP 702mln, while Altice share rose 5% following commentary that Co. has Mirova, Macquaries and KKR as frontrunners for a fibre JV.

FX

NZD/GBP

The Kiwi has been boosted by stronger than expected NZ CPI data overnight, and almost rallied to 0.6600 vs the Usd, while the Pound derived enough momentum from higher than forecast UK average earnings to breach 1.3200, albeit briefly amidst ongoing Brexit fall-out from the failure to clinch an agreement in time for this week’s EU summit that in turn was a prerequisite for another one in November to finalise a withdrawal deal.

CAD/EUR/AUD

All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, as the DXY continues to pivot 95.000, with the Loonie rebounding from recent 1.3000+ lows after a somewhat mixed BoC business survey on Monday (are rather redundant given that it was conducted pre-USMCA), while the single currency stalled around 1.1600 again and hampered by downbeat ZEW investor sentiment readings. Eur/Usd is just holding above 1.1565 lows, but could be drawn towards hefty option expiries at the 1.1550 strike (1.3 bn ahead of the NY cut). Elsewhere, the Aud did not get any independent support from RBA minutes largely sticking to a neutral stance, but has been caught in the cross-fire from relative Nzd outperformance as that pairing retreats through 1.0900 and 1.0850, plus ‘strong’ technical support between 1.0860-35 along the way.

JPY/CHF   

A reversal in fortunes for the safe-havens as Asia-Pac stocks put in a relatively resilient performance after recent heavy declines and with Usd/Jpy rebounding off a Fib (111.60) to trade back over 112.00, albeit now running in to decent supply said to be layered all the way up to 112.50. Note also, some big expiry interest containing the pair, with 3.1 bn from 111.60-75 and 1.3 bn at 112.50-65. The Franc has retreated from just shy of 0.9850 to meander within a 0.9900-0.9865 range.

FIXED INCOME

A relatively downbeat ZEW survey nudged Bunds just over parity to a new 158.61 Eurex peak (+2 ticks vs -1/4 point at worst), and appears to be protecting the core Eurozone debt future from further outperformance at the margins, as Italian BTPs continue to squeeze higher. Indeed, following pretty positive comments from Eurogroup head Centeno who stated that Italy does not pose a risk, the 10 year bond has rallied over 121.00, albeit belatedly, while Portuguese paper extends its post-S&P outlook upgrade ascent. However, Gilts and US Treasuries remain close to their lows post-UK data and pre-IP respectively.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are both lower by over 0.5% with the prices approaching USD 71.00/bbl and USD 81.00/bbl to the downside respectively in anticipation of an increase in U.S inventories, where the EIA noted shale oil output is expected to rise to a record 7.7mln BPD in November. Traders will be keeping an eye on the weekly API crude inventory data released later today and any developments in Saudi in regards to the missing journalist.

Gold is marginally higher in a continuation of market risk aversion as investors seek the yellow metal; with prices pivoting near two-and-a-half month highs. Elsewhere, copper slid 1.5% with the red metal facing its biggest one-day loss in over a week as escalating US-Sino trade tensions weighed on sentiment and demand outlook. Meanwhile, steel demand forecasts from WorldSteel have doubled for both 2018 and 2019, although trade tensions mean that industry risks remain. Finally, Chinese rebar futures pulled back from near-four-week highs, while analysts noted that steel prices in China will remain supported by the country’s resolve to reduce excess and outdated capacity.

BofA Merrill Lynch October Fund Manager Survey finds investors most bearish on global growth since 2007
content:
• BofA Merrill Lynch October Fund Manager Survey finds investors most bearish on global growth since 2007, BofAML says
  • Average cash balance holds steady at 5.1%, well above the 10-year average of 4.5%, as investors stay bearish, , BofAML's survey finds
  • BofAML says a record 85% of survey respondents think the global economy is in the late cycle, 11ppt above prior highs in Dec. ‘07
  • When asked how the global economy will develop over the next year, net 38% of respondents expect deceleration, the worst outlook on global growth since Nov. ‘08
  • FMS investors think the USD is very overvalued, notably against EM currencies which are seen as never having been more undervalued in survey history
  • Looking at corporate earnings, net 35% of respondents indicated they do not expect an improvement of 10% or more in the next year, a significant swing from net 35% expecting improvement from February’s survey
  • A net 20% of investors surveyed think global profits will deteriorate over the next 12 months, a 2-year low and major reversal from January’s survey, when a net 39% noted they expected an improvement

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets partially shrugged-off the tech-led losses on Wall St and traded mostly higher as focus shifted on earnings updates. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was led by mining names after the recent strength in gold prices and with Rio Tinto shares supported following its Q3 production update in which iron ore shipments declined Y/Y but the Co. affirmed FY18 shipments at the upper end of its guidance range. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and Japanese exporters coat-tailed on favourable currency moves, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) initially conformed to the upbeat tone as participants brushed aside continued PBoC liquidity inaction and took encouragement from the numerous corporate positive profit alerts, although Chinese bourses then failed to sustain the gains and gradually slipped into negative territory.

FTSE

BP (BP/ LN) / Eni (ENI IM) – Co.’s are expected to commence exploratory drilling in Libya at the front end of Q1 2019; according to the chairman of Libya’s NOC. (The Telegraph)

BHP (BLT LN) - Co. raised stake in SolGold to 11.2% from around 6% in which SolGold are to issue 100mln shares to BHP. (FT)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Co. has decided to not proceed with the Rolleston coal mine sale after failing to strike an agreement. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) - Co. Q3 Pilbara iron ore shipments 81.9mln tons vs. Prev. 85.8mln tons Y/Y. Q3 Pilbara iron ore output 82.5mln tons vs. Prev. 85.0mln tons Y/Y. Co. Q3 mined copper output 159.7K tons vs. Prev. 120.6K tons Y/Y. Co. says Pilbara shipments expected at upper end of previously announced range. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. will keep it’s freeze on manufacturing investments in Britain if the EU exit fails to provide enough clarity on future trading relations; quoted from the chairman. (Newswires)

Burberry (BRBY LN) – It will begin releasing limited edition clothes and products every month; adding it to a increasing number of luxury sector brands trying to increase collection releases to keep clients hooked. (Newswires)

Royal Mail (RMG LN) – Around 140k employees are now able to sell shares they were given at privatisation. (The Guardian)

Gambling names – Co.’s could be forced to go without tens of millions of pounds in profit as ministers are looking to change betting rules. The reduction in the maximum stake for fixed-odds betting terminals from GBP 100 to GBP 2 was initially scheduled for April 2020, but now could be implemented during 2019. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Babcock (BAB LN) – An analysis of the Co. alleges Babcock “systematically misled investors by burying bad news about its performance”, while management  claimed there were problems with work for the MoD, Babcock’s largest customer, and labelled relations with the department as “terrible”. (The Telegraph)

ConvaTec (CTEC LN) – Co. CEO resigned effective immediately and has been replaced by Rick Anderson. (The Times)

Linde (LIN GY) – Co. said it had completed work with the US FTC on remedies to secure the approval of the proposed merger with Praxair (PX). (Newswires)

Merck (MRK GY) – Co. aims to return to profitable growth as of 2019, Co. affirmed expectations for FY 2018 business performance. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Faurecia (EO FP) – Co. stated that its board of directors co-opted Gregoire Olivier to board to replace Carlos Tavares for remaining duration of Carlos Tavares mandate. (Newswires)

Safran (SAF FP) – Co. has improved the design of its Silvercrest engine to prevent factory delay repeats, with further testing planned in the second quarter of next year to confirm this; according to their head of engines division. (Newswires)

content:

  • Asian equity markets partially shrugged-off the tech-led losses on Wall St and traded mostly higher as focus shifted on earnings updates
  • In FX markets, most major pairs were quiet as the DXY consolidated following yesterday’s pressure in which it just about held above 95.00
  • European Council President Tusk said Brexit is more complicated than expected and that EU must prepare for no-deal scenario
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK labour market report, German ZEW, US industrial production, supply from Germany and a slew of large cap earnings

ASIA

Asian equity markets partially shrugged-off the tech-led losses on Wall St and traded mostly higher as focus shifted on earnings updates. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was led by mining names after the recent strength in gold prices and with Rio Tinto shares supported following its Q3 production update in which iron ore shipments declined Y/Y but the Co. affirmed FY18 shipments at the upper end of its guidance range. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and Japanese exporters coat-tailed on favourable currency moves, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) initially conformed to the upbeat tone as participants brushed aside continued PBoC liquidity inaction and took encouragement from the numerous corporate positive profit alerts, although Chinese bourses then failed to sustain the gains and gradually slipped into negative territory. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they tracked weakness in T-notes, with prices also subdued by the improved risk tone in Japan and reduced demand at the 5yr JGB auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations again for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9119 (Prev. 6.9154)

Chinese CPI (Sep) Y/Y 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.3%). (Newswires)
Chinese PPI (Sep) Y/Y 3.6% vs. Exp. 3.5% (Prev. 4.1%)
 

UK/EU

European Council President Tusk said Brexit is more complicated than expected and that EU must prepare for no-deal scenario. Tusk added that a no-deal Brexit more likely than it was before and stated the fact that we are preparing for a no-deal scenario must not, under any circumstances, lead us away from making every effort to reach the best agreement possible, for all sides. Furthermore, Tusk also noted that he invited UK PM May to address remaining EU 27 member states on Wednesday night. (Newswires)

UK Leader of the Commons, Andrea Leadsom hosted a meeting in her office last night with 8 ministers who share concerns over PM May’s Brexit plans. The Telegraph suggests that the scale and the seniority of the meeting is likely to be of concern for Downing Street. (Telegraph)

UK Chancellor Hammond will need GBP 19bln from higher taxes, extra borrowing or faster-than-expected growth if this month’s budget is to fulfil the prime minister’s promises to end austerity and boost NHS spending, according to the IFS. (Guardian)

ECB Vice President de Guindos said Eurozone should continue to grow at an above-trend rate and noted that core inflation is moderate but should rise. Furthermore, he commented that risks include oil prices and the uncertainty from populism, while he added that Spain's economic recovery may have peaked. (Newswires)

Italy's PM Conte said Italy's cabinet approved 2019 budget and that the budget draft is to be sent to the Commission, while he added that the budget keeps the government's promises and keeps public accounts in order. Elsewhere, Italy's Economy Minister Tria said the budget measures are all fully covered and budget allows early retirement as well as basic income tools, while the League said there are no tax hikes in budget except on banks and insurers. (Newswires)

The Dutch government will lower corporation tax to 20.5% from 25%. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, most major pairs were quiet as the DXY consolidated following yesterday’s pressure in which it just about held above 95.00, while major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD traded rangebound at the 1.1500 and 1.3100 handles respectively. As such, the Asia-Pac currencies took much of the attention overnight in which USD/JPY briefly reclaimed the 112.00 level on safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans were mixed with AUD unmoved after an unsurprising RBA minutes which mostly kept to reiterations and with NZD/USD struggling to hold on to the gains seen in the aftermath of firmer than expected CPI data from New Zealand which edged closer towards the 2% inflation target mid-point.

RBA minutes from October 2nd meeting reiterated that the board agreed there was no strong case for near-term rate move and that the next move is likely to be upwards. RBA minutes also noted the board agreed keeping rates steady is a source of stability and confidence, while the board was noted to be uncertain regarding consumption due to subdued income growth and decline in home prices. (Newswires)

New Zealand CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
New Zealand CPI (Q2) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.5%)
RBNZ Sectoral Factor Model Inflation Gauge (Q3) 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures traded flat as resistance at USD 72.00/bbl capped upside. Elsewhere, gold was also contained as the greenback consolidated overnight, while copper underperformed after the deterioration of sentiment in late US trade and as China failed to sustain the early positive momentum.

Goldman Sachs revised 3-month gold forecasts tp USD 1250/ounce (Prev. USD 1350), 6-month revised to USD 1300/ounce (Prev. USD 1375) and 12-month revised to USD 1325/ounce (Prev. 1450). (Newswires)

World Steel Association sees global steel demand to increase 3.9% to around 1.66bln tons in 2018 and global steel demand to increase 1.4% to around 1.68bln tons in 2019, while it forecasts China 2018 steel demand to increase 6% to 781mln tons in 2018 and China steel demand to be flat in 2019. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

Saudi Arabia are to say journalist Khashoggi died from a botched interrogation and that the intent was to abduct him from Turkey. (CNN) In related news, a source stated that Turkish prosecutors found evidence of killing at the Saudi consulate. (Al Jazeera)
 

US

Treasuries were lower on Monday though action remained in a tight range, with mixed retail sales only giving the complex a temporary boost. Less volatility also contributed to yields moving upwards; yields across the curve were higher by c.2bps across the curve at settlement. 10s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.1bps. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 6 ticks.

US President Trump lawyer said the judge dismissed Stormy Daniels lawsuit, while the judge reportedly stated Trump is entitled to legal fees from Stormy Daniels following the case dismissal. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia sentiment brightens as focus turned to earnings & production updates
content: Asian equity markets partially shrugged-off the tech-led losses on Wall St and traded mostly higher as focus shifted on earnings updates. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was led by mining names after the recent strength in gold prices and with Rio Tinto shares supported following its Q3 production update in which iron ore shipments declined Y/Y but the Co. affirmed FY18 shipments at the upper end of its guidance range. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and Japanese exporters coat-tailed on favourable currency moves, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) initially conformed to the upbeat tone as participants brushed aside continued PBoC liquidity inaction and took encouragement from the numerous corporate positive profit alerts, although Chinese bourses then failed to sustain the gains and gradually slipped into negative territory. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they tracked weakness in T-notes, with prices also subdued by the improved risk tone in Japan and reduced demand at the 5yr JGB auction.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia shrugs of Wall St losses as focus shifts to production updates and positive profit alerts
content:
Asia equity markets trade higher as the region shrugs-off the tech-led losses on Wall St and with focus shifting on earnings updates. ASX 200 (+0.5%) is led by mining names after the recent strength in gold prices and with Rio Tinto shares gaining after its Q3 production update in which iron ore shipments declined Y/Y but the Co. affirmed FY18 shipments at the upper end of its guidance range. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and Japanese exporters coat-tail on favourable currency moves, while Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) and Hang Seng (+0.4%) conform to the upbeat tone as participants brush aside continued PBoC liquidity inaction and take encouragement from the numerous corporate positive profit alerts.

In FX markets, most major pairs are quiet as the DXY consolidates following yesterday’s pressure and just about holds above 95.00, while major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD are rangebound at the 1.1500 and 1.3100 handles respectively. As such, the Asia-Pac currencies took much of the attention overnight with USD/JPY briefly reclaiming the 112.00 level on safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans are mixed with AUD unmoved after an unsurprising RBA minutes which mostly kept to reiterations and with NZD/USD holding onto most the gains seen in the aftermath of firmer than expected CPI data from New Zealand which edged closer towards the 2% inflation target mid-point at 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.5%).

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they track weakness in T-notes, with demand subdued by the improved risk tone and ahead of a 5yr JGB auction later.

PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the October 2nd meeting where the central bank kept rates on hold at the record low of 1.50% as expected, due at 0130BST/1930CDT/0830HKT
content:
The RBA are to release the minutes from the October meeting where the central bank held the Cash Rate Target at the record low of 1.50%. This was in-line with consensus as ASX 30 Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures had indicated a 100% expectation the central bank would keep policy unchanged.

At the meeting, the RBA reiterated that low rates are supporting the economy and stated that progress on inflation expected to be gradual but that it sees inflation higher in 2019 and 2020. Furthermore, RBA added that wage growth remains low which is likely to continue for a while but stated that outlook for labor market and business conditions are positive.

As a guide, AUD/USD saw only mild support following the policy announcement and statement despite the comments not providing anything particularly surprising, as the tone of the statement was slightly upbeat and did little to alter the perception regarding the likelihood for the next move in rates to be a hike rather than a cut.
